llm_message:
Eligibility:
Quotes: "Eighty-one patients with chronic stroke, traumatic brain injury (TBI) and multiple sclerosis (MS) were recruited; 50 out of 81 received one month of H-CAD intervention, with one training session a day lasting 30 minutes for 5 days a week."
"The hypothesis is that the H-CAD system is at least as effective as the usual care for arm/hand function, measured with outcome measures for arm/hand function, given to the stroke, TBI and MS patients when they are living at home."
Reasoning: The trial included a broad range of patients with stroke, TBI, and MS, which is similar to the patient population that would receive this intervention in usual care. However, the trial still had some exclusion criteria (e.g. excluding those who couldn't participate in the study assessments). Overall, the eligibility criteria were fairly pragmatic but not identical to usual care.
Score: [4]

Recruitment:
Quotes: "Patients were recruited from Unità Organica di Riabilitazione Intensiva Neuromotoria (UORIN, Italy), Foundation Institute Guttmann (FPING, Spain) and from National Multiple Sclerosis Centre (NMSC, Belgium)."
Reasoning: Patients were recruited from rehabilitation centers in multiple countries. This recruitment approach is more targeted than recruiting through usual care appointments, but still fairly pragmatic as it involves real-world clinical settings where these patients would typically be treated. It's not clear if any additional recruitment efforts beyond usual care were made.
Score: [4]

Setting:
Quotes: "The tele-rehabilitation service is mainly addressed to neurological patients after traumatic brain injury (TBI), stroke or multiple sclerosis (MS)."
"For this reason, in the following of the present paper it will be named "H-CAD" system. The instrumented desk allows the execution and monitoring of a configurable set of home exercises the professionals may purposely design to improve the main arm functions."
Reasoning: The intervention was designed to be used in the home setting under remote supervision from the hospital. This matches the intended real-world setting of use for a tele-rehabilitation service. The trial itself was conducted in the home setting.
Score: [5]  

Organization:
Quotes: "The tele-rehabilitation service is mainly addressed to neurological patients after traumatic brain injury (TBI), stroke or multiple sclerosis (MS)."
Reasoning: The H-CAD system is designed as a tele-rehabilitation service that can be used at home with remote supervision from clinicians. This matches how the organization of the intervention would be in usual care, without requiring additional staff, resources, or changes to the care delivery process.
Score: [5]

Flexibility (delivery):
Quotes: "The H-CAD system maintained the same functional ability in the group of patients who underwent the intervention of the H-CAD system compared to usual care."
"The H-CAD parameters received from H-CAD system during the month of intervention were analyzed and a possible improvement in execution the exercises. The analyzed exercises were book, pencil, keyboard, jar, checkers, and light bulb."
Reasoning: The delivery of the H-CAD intervention allowed for some flexibility, as it involved practicing a variety of different functional exercises. However, the exercises were still standardized and consistent with the H-CAD system protocol. The flexibility appears to be similar to what would be expected in usual care tele-rehabilitation.
Score: [4]

Flexibility (adherence):
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified. The study does not discuss flexibility of participant adherence to the H-CAD intervention.
Reasoning: There is insufficient information provided to assess the flexibility of participant adherence to the intervention. The study does not mention anything about this aspect.
Score: [NA] 

Follow-up:
Quotes: "The ARA test was chosen as the main outcome measure because all the patients were able to perform the total test compared to the WMFT test where the patient has to stand up for some exercises - impossible for major visual problems."
"The H-CAD parameters received from H-CAD system during the month of intervention were analyzed to detect a possible improvement in executing the exercises."
Reasoning: The main outcome measures (ARA test and H-CAD system parameters) were collected before and after the 1-month intervention period. This matches typical follow-up intensity for tele-rehabilitation in usual care. No additional unscheduled follow-up visits were mentioned.
Score: [4]

Primary outcome:
Quotes: "The Action Research Arm (ARA) and the Nine Hole Peg Test (NHPT) were used as main outcome measures. They proved the H-CAD system to be at least as effective as usual care."
Reasoning: The primary outcome measures (ARA and NHPT) assess functional ability of the affected arm, which is directly relevant to stroke, TBI and MS patients. These outcomes are likely to be used in regular care as well. The measures do not require specialized equipment or expertise beyond what's available in usual care.
Score: [5]

Primary analysis:
Quotes: "A total of 16 stroke patients were included in the study, 30 TBI patients and 35 MS patients. The average time since the start of the diagnosis was 9.9 years (range 1-35 years). Information about inclusion rate and number of patient data available at each measurement moment is presented in Figure 1."
Reasoning: The primary analysis appears to include all patients with available data at each timepoint, which is a pragmatic approach. There is no mention of excluding patients who did not adhere to the protocol. However, the information provided is limited, so it's not entirely clear if the analysis was a true intention-to-treat with all randomized participants.
Score: [4]

llm_message:
Eligibility:
Quotes: "Subjects were 69 people with MS, 52 of whom took part in the trial (Fig. 1). Inclusion criteria were patients in South East London, living with MS and deemed by clinicians) to have one or more of unresolved symptoms, psychosocial concerns, end-of-life issues, progressive illness, or complex needs (i.e., palliative care needs)."
The eligibility criteria were quite broad, including patients with various unresolved symptoms, psychosocial concerns, end-of-life issues, progressive illness, or complex needs related to MS. This represents a relatively pragmatic approach, although limiting to a specific geographic area (South East London) and requiring clinician judgment of palliative care needs adds some explanatory elements.
Score: [4]

Recruitment:
Quotes: "Patients in South East London who were severely affected by MS were referred by clinicians to the trial. After baseline interview, patients were randomly allocated to either a multiprofessional palliative care team (PCT) immediately (fast track) or the control care group who continued best usual care for three months and then were offered the PCT."
Patients were recruited through referrals from clinicians, which is similar to how patients would be identified for palliative care services in usual care. No additional efforts beyond usual care procedures appear to have been made to recruit patients.
Score: [5]  

Setting:
Quotes: "Patients in South East London who were severely affected by MS were referred by clinicians to the trial."
The trial was limited to a single geographic area (South East London), but recruited from multiple clinicians seeing MS patients in that area. This leans more explanatory than recruiting from multiple centers that are representative of a wider usual care setting.
Score: [3]

Organization:
Quotes: "Subjects were 69 people with MS, 52 of whom took part in the trial (Fig. 1)" [...] " Patients were randomized to receive either the PCT immediately (fast track) or usual best practice alone (control) for 12 weeks, after which they were offered the service."
The delivery of palliative care by the PCT appears to be an increase in resources and expertise compared to usual care. Patients in the control group continued usual best practice care. The PCT undertook assessments and provided specialist welfare benefits advice and bereavement support beyond what is likely in usual care.
Score: [2]

Flexibility (delivery):
Quotes: "After initial assessment, treatment was recommended." "Much of the work was in patients' homes, with some specialist contact in hospital being reported. Interestingly, contrary to initial concerns, input from MS nurses was not lower in the fast-track group—in fact there was a nonsignificant trend for it to be higher."
There are no details provided on flexibility of the PCT intervention protocol. It seems treatment was recommended after initial assessment, but the degree of flexibility is unclear. Much of the PCT care occurred in patients' homes which suggests some flexibility to adapt to the setting. On balance, there is insufficient information to score this domain.
Score: [NA]

Flexibility (adherence):
The full text does not mention any information about flexibility in how participants could engage with or adhere to the palliative care intervention. This domain does not appear to be applicable, as the intervention was a service provided to patients rather than requiring particular adherence on their part.
Score: [NA]

Follow-up:
Quotes: "We conducted face-to-face interviews with patients and caregivers. At baseline, we collected demographic and clinical data, and the patient's functional status (using the Expanded Disability Status Scale [EDSS]) and interviewer-assessed using the Expanded Disability Status Scale [EDSS], administered by a consultant neurologist (E. S.)). We collected outcome and cost data at baseline (before randomization) and at 6, 12, 18 (only control group—after they received PCT), and 24 weeks."
Data collection involved face-to-face interviews with patients and caregivers at multiple timepoints, as well as assessment of functional status by a neurologist. This represents a more explanatory approach with more extensive data collection than would be typical in usual care.
Score: [2]

Primary outcome:
Quotes: "Our standardized questionnaires included the Palliative Care Outcome Scale (POS-8), comprising eight questions on anxiety, patient and carer concerns, and practical needs, each rated 0–4; a single-item POS pain score (rated 0 [best] to 4 [worst]); and caregivers' burden (using the 12-item version of the Zarit Carer Burden Inventory [ZBI])."
The primary palliative care outcome measures (POS-8, pain score, caregiver burden) are directly relevant to patients and caregivers. However, using standardized questionnaires and scales represents a more explanatory approach than would typically be captured in routine usual care.
Score: [3]

Primary analysis:
Quotes: "We planned an intention-to-treat analysis, irrespective of whether patients were assessed as having palliative care needs or the nature of contact with the PCT. We tested the differences between the two arms (expressed as differences between follow-up and baseline interviews) using one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA), checking statistical assumptions and adjusting for baseline scores. Our primary point of analysis was at 12 weeks (before the control group received the PCT)."
The primary analysis was planned as an intention-to-treat analysis, which is a pragmatic approach that includes all randomized participants regardless of their contact with the intervention. However, the analysis used ANOVA adjusting for baseline scores, which is a more explanatory approach than would be used in usual care settings.
Score: [4]

llm_message:
Eligibility:
Quotes: "Eligibility criteria for patients: diagnosis RRMS since at least one year, EDSS score ≤4.0, no symptoms suggestive of a relapse, no relapse in the preceding four weeks, willing and capable of participating in the investigations, and having access to the internet."
"The study population was low-disability RRMS patients with or without support partner."

The eligibility criteria are fairly pragmatic, including low-disability RRMS patients diagnosed at least one year ago with EDSS ≤4.0 and no recent relapses. This represents a typical population seen in usual care. However, the requirement for internet access and willingness/capability to participate in investigations is slightly more restrictive than usual care.
Score: [4]

Recruitment:
Quotes: "Participants were recruited from all over the Netherlands by the patient organisation NMSF, Rotterdam, the Netherlands. Interested patients were contacted by a registered nurse experienced in MS (MH) by phone to check diagnosis and eligibility criteria."

Recruitment was done through the patient organization NMSF, rather than during usual care appointments. Interested patients were then screened by phone by a study nurse. This represents a more targeted recruitment effort compared to usual care.
Score: [2]

Setting:
Quotes: "We did a single-centre, randomized (1:1), unmasked, parallel-group, controlled trial in the Netherlands."

The trial was conducted at a single center in the Netherlands. While not explicitly stated, this appears to be an academic or specialized center rather than a usual care community setting.
Score: [2] 

Organization:
Quotes: "The multidisciplinary team included a psychiatrist, psychiatric nurse, neurologist, registered nurse specialized in MS, physiotherapist, dance therapist, and a person with MS [9]. All professional team members were formally trained in their respective disciplines and all members were experienced in the field of MS."
"The person with MS had experience with chronic symptoms and multiple disease-modifying treatments. As the team members were also involved in the preceding observational study—except for the dance therapist-, the team was experienced in providing CDT [9]."

The multidisciplinary team providing the intervention included specialists that would not typically be available in usual care for MS, such as a psychiatrist, psychiatric nurse, dance therapist, etc. The team members had specific experience in MS and the CDT intervention from a prior observational study. This represents a higher level of expertise and training than would be available in usual care.
Score: [2]

Flexibility (delivery):
Quotes: "CDT is a social cognitive theory-based intervention aiming to uncover and promote existing capabilities, with the notion 'stressor' as central concept [9]. CDT is based on the identification and reduction of stressors, client-centred group sessions and the use of another significant informal caregiver group sessions; and self-reliance, autonomy and acceptance as central themes [9]. CDT focuses on the exploration of those stressors that confine patients to their physical, psychological or social roles regarding their disease and limitations; reduces relevant stressors; explores and pushes personal boundaries by making optimal use of the existing potential [9]."

The intervention has a structured protocol based on social cognitive theory principles. While some tailoring to the individual is mentioned, such as identifying personal stressors and boundaries, overall the delivery appears to be fairly standardized without much flexibility. No discussion of allowed co-interventions or management of complications.
Score: [2]

Flexibility (adherence):
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified. The intervention involves attending group sessions, but there is no mention of any measures to monitor or enforce patient adherence.
Score: [NA]

Follow-up:
Quotes: "Assessments were at baseline and at one, three and six months."
"Follow-up assessments were at one, three and six months. Primary endpoint was control self-efficacy (Multiple Sclerosis Self-Efficacy Scale Control [MSSES-C] (minimum 90, maximum 900) at six months."

Follow-up assessments were conducted at 1, 3 and 6 months, with the primary endpoint at 6 months. This schedule is more frequent than typical follow-up for low-disability RRMS patients in usual care. No unscheduled visits are mentioned.
Score: [2]

Primary outcome:
Quote: "The primary study outcome was the change in control self-efficacy, assessed by the Multiple Sclerosis Self-Efficacy Scale (MSSES), at six months [12]. The MSSES is a specific and sensitive self-report questionnaire consisting of two 9-items subscales for control and functional self-efficacy, with a high internal consistency and test-retest reliability [12]."

The primary outcome is self-efficacy, assessed using the Multiple Sclerosis Self-Efficacy Scale (MSSES), a patient-reported outcome measure. This is relevant to participants and does not require assessment expertise beyond usual care. However, self-efficacy is a more indirect outcome compared to clinical measures of disability or disease activity that would be used in usual care.
Score: [4]

Primary analysis:
Quotes: "The baseline and follow-up values for the primary, secondary and tertiary outcomes in both groups, and the between-group differences at follow-up are presented in Table 2. At six months the MSSES-C score did not statistically significantly differ between the two groups."
"Multiple regression analysis with age, gender, disease duration, EDSS score and education as independent variables and MSSES-C at six months as a dependent variable showed no associations. At six months, 31 of 54 (57.4%) CDT patients and 26 of 56 (46.4%) control patients had an improved control self-efficacy, whereby improvement was defined as an increase of at least 75 points compared to baseline, being ≥0.5 SD baseline (n = 155)."

The primary analysis looked at between-group differences in MSSES-C scores at 6 months. A multiple regression analysis adjusting for baseline variables was also performed. Missing data and approach for handling missing data are not discussed. It's unclear if the analysis was intention-to-treat or per-protocol. 57% of CDT and 46% of control patients were analyzed as having improvement in self-efficacy.
Score: [3]

Organization:
Quotes: "The multidisciplinary team included a psychiatrist, psychiatric nurse, neurologist, registered nurse specialized in MS, physiotherapist, dance therapist, and a person with MS [9]. All professional team members were formally trained in their respective disciplines and all members were experienced in the field of MS."
"The person with MS had experience with chronic symptoms and multiple disease-modifying treatments. As the team members were also involved in the preceding observational study—except for the dance therapist-, the team was experienced in providing CDT [9]."

The multidisciplinary team providing the intervention included specialists that would not typically be available in usual care for MS, such as a psychiatrist, psychiatric nurse, dance therapist, etc. The team members had specific experience in MS and the CDT intervention from a prior observational study. This represents a higher level of expertise and training than would be available in usual care.
Score: [2]

Flexibility (delivery):
Quotes: "CDT is a social cognitive theory-based intervention aiming to uncover and promote existing capabilities, with the notion 'stressor' as central concept [9]. CDT is based on the identification and reduction of stressors, client-centred group sessions and the use of another significant informal caregiver group sessions; and self-reliance, autonomy and acceptance as central themes [9]. CDT focuses on the exploration of those stressors that confine patients to their physical, psychological or social roles regarding their disease and limitations; reduces relevant stressors; explores and pushes personal boundaries by making optimal use of the existing potential [9]."

The intervention has a structured protocol based on social cognitive theory principles. While some tailoring to the individual is mentioned, such as identifying personal stressors and boundaries, overall the delivery appears to be fairly standardized without much flexibility. No discussion of allowed co-interventions or management of complications.
Score: [2]

Flexibility (adherence):
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified. The intervention involves attending group sessions, but there is no mention of any measures to monitor or enforce patient adherence.
Score: [NA]

Follow-up:
Quotes: "Assessments were at baseline and at one, three and six months."
"Follow-up assessments were at one, three and six months. Primary endpoint was control self-efficacy (Multiple Sclerosis Self-Efficacy Scale Control [MSSES-C] (minimum 90, maximum 900) at six months."

Follow-up assessments were conducted at 1, 3 and 6 months, with the primary endpoint at 6 months. This schedule is more frequent than typical follow-up for low-disability RRMS patients in usual care. No unscheduled visits are mentioned.
Score: [2]

Primary outcome:
Quote: "The primary study outcome was the change in control self-efficacy, assessed by the Multiple Sclerosis Self-Efficacy Scale (MSSES), at six months [12]. The MSSES is a specific and sensitive self-report questionnaire consisting of two 9-items subscales for control and functional self-efficacy, with a high internal consistency and test-retest reliability [12]."

The primary outcome is self-efficacy, assessed using the Multiple Sclerosis Self-Efficacy Scale (MSSES), a patient-reported outcome measure. This is relevant to participants and does not require assessment expertise beyond usual care. However, self-efficacy is a more indirect outcome compared to clinical measures of disability or disease activity that would be used in usual care.
Score: [4]

Primary analysis:
Quotes: "The baseline and follow-up values for the primary, secondary and tertiary outcomes in both groups, and the between-group differences at follow-up are presented in Table 2. At six months the MSSES-C score did not statistically significantly differ between the two groups."
"Multiple regression analysis with age, gender, disease duration, EDSS score and education as independent variables and MSSES-C at six months as a dependent variable showed no associations. At six months, 31 of 54 (57.4%) CDT patients and 26 of 56 (46.4%) control patients had an improved control self-efficacy, whereby improvement was defined as an increase of at least 75 points compared to baseline, being ≥0.5 SD baseline (n = 155)."

The primary analysis looked at between-group differences in MSSES-C scores at 6 months. A multiple regression analysis adjusting for baseline variables was also performed. Missing data and approach for handling missing data are not discussed. It's unclear if the analysis was intention-to-treat or per-protocol. 57% of CDT and 46% of control patients were analyzed as having improvement in self-efficacy.
Score: [3]

llm_message:
Eligibility:
Quotes:
1. "Inclusion criteria were: 1) having a definite diagnosis of MS from a neurologist; 2) being within 5 years of receiving a diagnosis of MS; 3) scoring at least 10 on the Beck Depression Inventory-II (BDI-II) [26]; 4) not currently undertaking other psychological treatment for depressive or anxiety symptoms for the length of participation in the current trial; 5) speak English fluently; 6) no current or lifetime diagnosis of psychosis; 7) no current substance dependency; 8) no gross cognitive impairment; and 9) no changes to medications prior and during involvement in the trial."

The eligibility criteria are somewhat stricter than what would be used in usual care, with several exclusions like no current substance dependency, no gross cognitive impairment, and no changes to medications. However, the criteria are not overly restrictive, allowing individuals with a definite MS diagnosis within 5 years who have at least mild depression. On balance, the eligibility criteria are moderately pragmatic.

Score: [3]

Recruitment:
Quotes:
1. "The study took place at a large teaching and research hospital in Melbourne, Australia. Participants were recruited through neurologists working in a large MS outpatient clinic at the hospital, advertisements on MS related websites and local press releases."

Recruitment occurred through a mix of usual care pathways (neurologists working in an MS clinic) and more targeted approaches (advertisements and press releases). This goes slightly beyond what would typically be done in usual care, but not excessively so. The recruitment methods are moderately pragmatic.

Score: [3]

Setting:
Quotes:
1. "The study took place at a large teaching and research hospital in Melbourne, Australia."

The trial took place in a single large teaching hospital, which is a more specialized setting than usual care that would likely include other settings like smaller community clinics. However, the hospital setting is not highly specialized or explanatory. The setting is moderately pragmatic.

Score: [3]

Organization:
Quotes:
1. "Clinicians who delivered the intervention were also involved in providing the assessment questionnaires to participants."
2. "One female senior clinical psychologist and one male provisional clinical psychologist undertook assessments. During this baseline interview, the goals and procedures were explained in detail and written consent was obtained from all participants."

The intervention involved trained clinical psychologists delivering the therapy and undertaking assessments, which requires more expertise and organization than would typically be available in usual care. However, the resources required do not appear to be extensive. The organization is moderately explanatory.

Score: [2]

Flexibility (delivery):
Quotes:
1. "The aim of the 8-week tailored intervention is to significantly decrease level of depressive symptoms (primary outcome), anxiety, fatigue and pain impact and to contribute to improvements in levels of quality of life, sleep difficulties, MS illness acceptance, active coping skills, social support and resilience (secondary outcomes) in those newly diagnosed with MS."
2. "The CBT intervention consisted of 8 individual modules which focused on CBT based principles and strategies. These strategies included progressive muscle relaxation, controlled breathing exercises, pleasant activity scheduling, problem solving skills, cognitive exercises which helped individuals identify, challenge and manage unhelpful thoughts and beliefs."

The intervention had a clear aim and involved delivery of 8 individual CBT-based modules covering a range of strategies. This suggests a moderately structured protocol, but with some flexibility to tailor the modules and strategies to each participant. The delivery flexibility is moderately pragmatic.

Score: [3]

Flexibility (adherence):
Quotes: None relevant.

The full text does not provide any information on flexibility of participant adherence to the intervention or how adherence was monitored or encouraged. There is insufficient information to assess this domain.

Score: [NA] 

Follow-up:
Quotes:
1. "Follow up assessments ended April, 2015. The trial was stopped after achieving a total number of 30 participants (15 in each group)."

The trial follow-up ended after recruiting 30 participants total. No information is provided on the intensity of follow-up assessments compared to usual care. There is insufficient information in the text to fully assess the follow-up pragmatism.

Score: [NA]

Primary outcome:
Quotes: 
1. "The primary outcome was level of depressive symptoms at post and 20 weeks follow up which was measured with the Beck Depression Inventory-II (BDI-II) [26]."

The primary outcome measure of depressive symptoms is highly relevant to participants. The BDI-II is a self-report measure that does not require extensive training to administer or interpret. Depressive symptoms were assessed at post-treatment and 20-week follow-up, which are typical time points. The primary outcome is very pragmatic.

Score: [5]

Primary analysis:
Quotes:
1. "Effect sizes from pre to post and pre to follow up were calculated using Cohen's d for each outcome measure. All statistical analyses included a sample of 30 participants at pre, post and 20 weeks follow up and were undertaken controlling for gender and ambulation status."

The primary analysis included all 30 participants and controlled for baseline gender and ambulation status. It appears to be an intention-to-treat approach including all participants, which is a pragmatic approach. However, the text does not specify how missing data was handled, if present. The primary analysis is moderately pragmatic.

Score: [4]

llm_message:
Eligibility:
Quotes: "Thirty-two participants with multiple sclerosis randomized into intervention or control groups." "Potential participants were excluded if they had experienced exacerbation of their multiple sclerosis symptoms three months prior to the study, or had any medical condition which may preclude them from taking part in the exercise intervention."
The trial had some exclusion criteria related to recent MS exacerbations and medical conditions that could prevent exercise participation. However, the criteria seem reasonable and not overly restrictive compared to what would be used in usual care for this population. The trial aimed to include a representative sample of people with moderate MS.
Score: [4]

Recruitment:
Quotes: "Of the 873 patients on the clinical register for multiple sclerosis 159 patients were deemed suitable for the study. These people were sent invitation letters and participant information sheets. Forty-three potential participants expressed an interest in participating."
Recruitment was done by sending invitation letters to potentially eligible participants identified from a clinical register. This is a bit more effort than would be used in usual care, but still a relatively pragmatic approach, as the letters were sent to people already on a register, not requiring additional screening or advertising.
Score: [4]

Setting:
Quotes: "Two community leisure centres."
The intervention was delivered in two community leisure centres, which is likely very similar to the setting in which such an exercise intervention would be delivered as part of usual care.
Score: [5]

Organization:
Quotes: "The intervention group received 12 weeks of twice weekly, 60-minute group exercise sessions, including mobility, balance and resistance exercises. The control group received usual care."
The organization of the intervention seems quite different from usual care, with specialized 60-minute group exercise sessions twice a week, including mobility, balance and resistance components. Usual care would likely not include such an intensive program.
Score: [2] 

Flexibility (delivery):
Quotes: "Participants assigned to the intervention group attended a leisure centre-based exercise class, twice weekly for 12 weeks. Each group was led by two instructors (one physiotherapist and one fitness instructor). The same physiotherapist was present at both sites; however fitness instructors were different between sites."
The intervention followed a defined 12-week protocol of twice weekly classes led by both a physiotherapist and fitness instructor. While there was likely some inherent flexibility, the overall program seems to be have been delivered in a reasonably structured and consistent way across the two sites.
Score: [3]

Flexibility (adherence):
Quotes: "Attendance of participants at each class was recorded." "On initial inspection our attendance rates (71%) appear lower than other studies with similar class-based methodology16,21,26,28 all of whom reported greater than 80% attendance."
Participant attendance at the exercise classes was recorded. The authors compared their 71% attendance rate to the >80% attendance in other similar studies, suggesting that they were tracking and aiming for a high degree of adherence to the twice weekly sessions. However, no explicit adherence-improving strategies were mentioned.
Score: [3]

Follow-up:
Quotes: "Outcome measures were carried out within the local hospital's rehabilitation unit. They were taken at baseline, after 8 and 12 weeks of the intervention period (i.e. either the exercise class or usual care)." "The Timed 25-Foot Walk Test35 was chosen as the primary outcome measure. The Timed 25-Foot Walk Test measures walking speed over a short distance and has shown good reliability and validity in the multiple sclerosis population as an individual component of the Multiple Sclerosis Functional Composite disability assessment.36,37"
Outcome assessments were conducted at the hospital at baseline, 8 weeks and 12 weeks. This follow-up is more intense than would be typical in usual care, especially with the primary outcome being a timed walking test that requires in-person assessment. However, the timing of follow-up at 8 and 12 weeks is not too far off from what might be done in usual care.
Score: [3]

Primary outcome:
Quotes: "The Timed 25-Foot Walk Test35 was chosen as the primary outcome measure. The Timed 25-Foot Walk Test measures walking speed over a short distance and has shown good reliability and validity in the multiple sclerosis population as an individual component of the Multiple Sclerosis Functional Composite disability assessment.36,37"
The primary outcome was walking speed as measured by the Timed 25-Foot Walk Test. This is a performance measure that is relevant to patients and can be conducted relatively quickly. It is part of a standard MS disability assessment. While it requires in-person evaluation, overall it is a reasonably pragmatic and patient-centered primary outcome.
Score: [4]

Primary analysis:
Quotes: "The recruitment and retention of participants missing classes due to other appointments, family/work commitments, transport problems, holidays or mild ill-health (e.g. common cold)." "For the primary outcome measure, the Timed 25-Foot Walk Test, the ANOVA results demonstrated no statistically significant difference over time (Table 2). Although there was no statistically significant improvement in the Timed 25-Foot Walk Test, the mean scores improved by 7.2 seconds (24%) in the intervention group compared with the 3 seconds (19%) in the control group."
The primary analysis is not described in detail, but appears to be a standard ANOVA that included all participants. Some mentions are made of participants missing classes for various reasons, but it does not appear any were excluded from the analysis, suggesting an intent-to-treat approach. However, without more details on handling of missing data, the exact analysis approach cannot be confirmed.
Score: [4]

llm_message:
Eligibility:
Quotes: "Specific inclusion criteria were (1) ambulatory (can walk 100 m, be capable of walking 100 metres without a walking aid corresponding to a classification of ⩽5.5 on the Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS),10 even if they do use an aid for daily activities; and (2) self-reported to be sedentary or irregularly active at time of study entry (i.e. do not exercise 30 minutes or more twice per week of moderate to vigorous activity)."
The eligibility criteria are quite specific, requiring participants to be ambulatory with EDSS score ≤5.5, and sedentary or irregularly active. This is more restrictive than what would be typical in usual care for people with multiple sclerosis.
Score: [2]

Recruitment:
Quotes: "People were recruited from four multiple sclerosis clinics in three Canadian cities and from posting on media sites. During the clinic visit, the treating neurologist introduced the study to their patients and referred them to the research assistant who further explained the study and assessed eligibility."
Recruitment was done through multiple sclerosis clinics and media sites, with neurologists introducing the study to patients. This is somewhat different from how recruitment would occur in usual care.
Score: [3]

Setting:
Quotes: "The target population was community dwelling individuals aged 19 to 65 who have been diagnosed after 1994 with multiple sclerosis."
The study was conducted in a community setting with participants living at home, which matches the setting of usual care for this population.
Score: [5]

Organization:
Quotes: "Two different types of exercise interventions were contrasted. MSTEP©, a personally adapted exercise regimen including a variety of exercises targeting endurance, muscular, and core strength, balance, flexibility, muscular power, and speed of movement. The goal of the MSTEP© programme is to promote regular bouts of activity most days per week, encouraging a balance between rest and activity, and taking into consideration the physical and emotional status and capacity of the person."
The MSTEP intervention involved a personalized, multimodal exercise program delivered by exercise therapists or instructors. This required extra training and resources compared to what would be available in usual care.
Score: [2]

Flexibility (delivery):
Quotes: "On Push Days, participants were instructed to do short bursts of moderate-high intensity exercise to their own tolerance (e.g. for 1–3 minutes) and then reduce to a more comfortable pace for 5–7 minutes and repeat as they are possible. Supplementary Material Tables 4S and 5S present the specifics of the MSTEP© programme."
The MSTEP intervention followed a specific protocol in terms of exercise types, intensity, and progression. However, it allowed flexibility for participants to exercise according to their own tolerance. This represents a balance between explanatory and pragmatic approaches.
Score: [3]

Flexibility (adherence):
Quotes: "All participants were contacted every two weeks during the first two months, then monthly thereafter by the exercise instructor by telephone or email for follow-up by the instructor. The purpose of follow-up contacts is to provide an opportunity to ask any questions they have and also to facilitate long-term retention in the study."
Participants received regular follow-up contacts from the exercise instructor to encourage adherence and retention. However, there is no mention of any measures taken to strictly enforce or monitor adherence.
Score: [3]

Follow-up:
Quotes: "The intention was to follow participants for the first year of the intervention when the exercise programme was designed and adjusted as needed and have a further follow-up after the second year."
The follow-up extended to 2 years after the start of the intervention, which is longer than typical in usual care. The assessments also involved four visits over the first year which is more frequent than standard care.
Score: [2]

Primary outcome:
Quotes: "Primary outcome was peak oxygen consumption (VO2peak) at 12 months; secondary outcomes were composite measures of physical function, fatigue, and health-related quality of life."
Peak oxygen consumption is a physiological measure that requires specific testing not used in usual care. The other outcomes of physical function, fatigue and quality of life are more relevant to participants.
Score: [2]  

Primary analysis:
Quotes: "A mixed effects model for VO2peak (continuous variable); interaction group × time non-significant, main effects only presented. The group effect is interpreted as the difference between groups averaged over time; as the 95% CI included the null value of 0, the group effect was non-significant."
The primary analysis used a mixed effects model including all participants. There is no mention of excluding any participants post-randomization. This suggests an intent-to-treat approach was used.
Score: [5]

llm_message:
Eligibility:
Quotes: "Subjects: Thirty people moderately to severely affected by MS (Extended Disability Status Score, EDSS, 6.5–8) were randomized to an intervention or control group."
Reasoning: The trial included participants with moderate to severe MS, with EDSS scores between 6.5 and 8. This represents a moderately pragmatic approach, as it includes a specific subgroup of MS patients rather than all MS patients that would be seen in usual care. However, the EDSS range of 6.5-8 is still fairly broad and likely represents the typical MS patients that would be treated with physiotherapy in practice.
Score: [3]

Recruitment:
Quotes: "Ninety-one potential participants were identified and sent a letter of invitation", "41 potential participants responded and screened"
Reasoning: Recruitment was done by sending invitation letters to potential participants identified from a database. This deviates from how patients would typically present for treatment in usual care, as it involves active outreach and recruitment efforts. However, the recruitment was still done from a population of patients with MS, likely identified through medical records or MS society databases, which is more pragmatic than recruitment using media advertisements or other more explanatory methods.
Score: [3]

Setting:
Quotes: "Setting: Community; subjects' homes."
Reasoning: The intervention was delivered in the participants' homes in the community. This closely matches the setting of usual care for a home-based physiotherapy program.
Score: [5]

Organization:
Quotes: "The intervention group received twice weekly, home-based physiotherapy for eight weeks and the control group received usual care."
Reasoning: The trial used a typical frequency and duration of physiotherapy (twice weekly for 8 weeks) delivered by a physiotherapist. This closely matches what would be feasible to provide in usual care, without requiring additional organizational resources or changes to the typical care delivery process.
Score: [4]

Flexibility (delivery):
Quotes: "Each session lasted up to 60 minutes, and a task-specific programme was developed by the treating physiotherapist which was reviewed at each of the three assessments."
Reasoning: The physiotherapy intervention allowed the treating therapist to develop an individualized program for each participant, which was reviewed and adjusted at assessments throughout the trial. This suggests a moderately flexible approach to intervention delivery, allowing the therapist to tailor the treatment to the individual. However, the 60 minute session length was specified. Overall this represents a balance between pragmatic flexibility and some fixed elements.
Score: [3]

Flexibility (adherence):
Quotes: The full text does not contain information on how participant adherence was monitored or encouraged.
Score: [NA]

Follow-up:
Quotes: "The following outcome measures were recorded at baseline, post-intervention (Week 8) and at follow-up (Week 16). Primary outcome measure: Multiple Sclerosis Impact Scale (MSIS29) and secondary outcome measures assessed physical impairment, MS symptoms, quality of life, mood, and disability."
Reasoning: Follow-up assessments were conducted at 8 weeks (immediately post-intervention) and at 16 weeks. This represents a typical follow-up schedule for evaluating the effects of a short-term physiotherapy program, and does not involve more frequent or extensive follow-up than would be expected in usual care. The outcome measures are questionnaires and assessments that would be feasible to implement in usual care.
Score: [4]

Primary outcome:
Quotes: "Primary outcome measure: Multiple Sclerosis Impact Scale (MSIS29)"
Reasoning: The primary outcome was the MSIS29, which is a patient-reported outcome measure of the physical and psychological impact of MS. This is a pragmatic and relevant outcome from the patient perspective. The measure is a questionnaire that can be feasibly administered in usual care without requiring specialized equipment or expertise.
Score: [5]

Primary analysis:
Quotes: "All outcome variables were summarized and comparisons made between groups and over time. Outcome variables that could be shown to be analysed using parametric procedures (e.g. F1M), were analysed using a two-factor repeated measures ANOVA with two factors being time (0, 8 and 16) and group (1,2), thus allowing for possible interaction effects to assess whether groups react differently over time."
Reasoning: The primary analysis was a repeated measures ANOVA comparing the intervention and control groups across the three assessment timepoints. This appears to be an intent-to-treat analysis including all participants with available data, which is a pragmatic approach. There is no mention of excluding participants based on adherence or protocol violations.
Score: [4]

llm_message:
Eligibility:
Quotes: "The disease course is very varied, but is progressive in nature in many people. Individuals with MS experience an array of symptoms and disabilities, which can place a major burden on those with MS and their families, as well as on health and social services and the economy sector."
"Two hundred and seventy-eight people with MS were invited to take part in the study. One hundred and eighty-nine people consented to take part (68%)."
The trial included a broad range of people with MS who experience symptoms and disabilities that place a burden on health services. However, only 68% of those invited consented to participate, suggesting there may have been some selection of participants who were more willing or able to engage in the intervention.
Score: [4]

Recruitment:
Quotes: "Two hundred and seventy-eight people with MS were invited to take part in the study. One hundred and eighty-nine people consented to take part (68%)."
The study recruited participants by inviting people with MS to take part. This appears to be a pragmatic approach using usual methods of engaging patients, without extra efforts beyond what would occur in usual care.
Score: [4]

Setting:
Quotes: "The study was conducted with people with MS living in the community."
"Participants were community based and lived in West London and in counties contiguous with Greater London."
The intervention was delivered to people living in the community in their usual settings. This is a very pragmatic approach using the same settings as would be involved in usual care.
Score: [5]

Organization:
Quotes: "The intervention comprised discussion of self-care based on client priorities, using an information booklet about self-care."
The intervention involved discussion with participants and provision of an information booklet, which does not appear to require significant extra resources, staff or training beyond what would be available in usual care. However, the full text does not give extensive details on the organizational resources required.
Score: [4]

Flexibility (delivery):
Quotes: "The discussions lasted between 1 and 2 hours and were conducted on two occasions, over a one month period."
The delivery of the intervention involved some structure, with discussions conducted over two 1-2 hour sessions in a one month period. However, the discussions were based on client priorities, suggesting some flexibility to adapt the content to the individual. Overall, the delivery appears to be a balance between some protocol structure and some flexibility.
Score: [3]

Flexibility (adherence):
Quotes: The full text does not contain any information on flexibility in how participants were expected to adhere to the intervention.
Score: [NA]

Follow-up:
Quotes: "Assessments were conducted at baseline and again six months later."
Participants were only followed up at 6 months, which is not more extensive than usual follow-up periods for this type of intervention. No unscheduled visits or extensive data collection beyond the outcome measures are mentioned.
Score: [4]

Primary outcome:
Quotes: "A range of physical and psychological scales was included in order to obtain a comprehensive evaluation of the intervention. Total scores on a postal version of the Barthel Index, a scale measuring mobility, the United Kingdom version of the SF-36 and one measure developed for the study; the Standard Day Dependency Record (SDDR), were the main outcome measures."
The primary outcomes were a mixture of measures relevant to participants' mobility, daily living activities, quality of life and dependency. These appear to be outcomes that would be important to participants.
Score: [4]

Primary analysis:
Quotes: "An independent person not involved in the study randomized each participant using random number tables, with odd/even number allocation to intervention/control group, with random draw."
"Seventy-three individuals were in the intervention group and 96 were in the control group."
The analysis appears to be intention-to-treat, including all randomized participants in the groups they were allocated to, even if they did not complete the intervention. 13 withdrew or were lost to follow-up but were still included in the analysis.
Score: [5]

llm_message:
Eligibility:
Quotes: "MS patients from the outpatient clinic of the Neurology Department of Pitié-Salpêtrière Hospital were prospectively enrolled in the study between March to July 2012. Inclusion criteria were: having MS (MacDonald criteria); being able to complete a questionnaire; and being in need for a multidisciplinary approach, defined by the requirement, in addition to the neurology specialist, of at least two different medical (rehabilitation specialist, neuro-urology specialist, psychiatrist) or allied health professionals (physiotherapist, occupational therapist, social worker, psychologist, and neuropsychologist)."
Reasoning: The eligibility criteria are somewhat stricter than what would be used in usual care, requiring patients to have MS, be able to complete a questionnaire, need a multidisciplinary approach, and require at least two different medical or allied health professionals. However, the criteria are not overly strict and would likely capture a majority of MS patients needing multidisciplinary care.
Score: [3]

Recruitment:
Quotes: "MS patients from the outpatient clinic of the Neurology Department of Pitié-Salpêtrière Hospital were prospectively enrolled in the study between March to July 2012."
Reasoning: Patients were recruited prospectively from the outpatient clinic of the hospital's neurology department. This is a very pragmatic approach that mirrors how patients would be recruited in usual care, without any extra effort or routes that would not normally be used.
Score: [5]

Setting:
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified. The study appears to have taken place at a single hospital (Pitié-Salpêtrière Hospital).
Reasoning: The trial seems to have been conducted at a single hospital. While this is likely a typical setting where MS patients would receive multidisciplinary care, the use of only a single center is more explanatory than recruiting across multiple centers that patients usually visit.
Score: [3]

Organization:
Quotes: "At the end of the visit, a summary of the multidisciplinary evaluation, along with the resulting therapeutic propositions, was discussed with the patient and caregivers. For patients in the control group, interventions with the different health professionals were planned after the inclusion visit, with an explanatory letter given to the patient or directly sent to the professionals. In most cases the same health professionals were in charge of the two groups."
Reasoning: The organization appears largely similar to usual care, with a multidisciplinary evaluation and discussion of therapeutic propositions with patients and caregivers. Interventions were planned after the visit. The same health professionals cared for both groups. No major differences in resources, expertise or organization compared to usual care are noted.
Score: [4]

Flexibility (delivery):
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified.
Reasoning: There is not enough information provided about the flexibility of intervention delivery compared to usual care. The involvement of the same health professionals in both groups suggests flexibility may have been similar to usual care, but this cannot be determined conclusively.
Score: [NA]

Flexibility (adherence):
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified. 
Reasoning: The trial does not appear to involve any flexibility in participant adherence, as it consisted of a single multidisciplinary evaluation rather than an ongoing intervention that participants needed to adhere to. Therefore, this domain is not applicable.
Score: [NA]

Follow-up:
Quotes: "Fifty MS patients were included. Median MSIS 29 score decreased over six months in the control group (−4.89) and increased in the IMD group (+2.00), with a significant difference between the two groups (p = 0.03). However, in the multivariate analysis, after adjustment of HAD-D and INTERMED score, this difference was no longer significant."
Reasoning: Patients were followed up at 6 months and 12 months after the initial multidisciplinary evaluation. This is likely somewhat more intense than the follow-up that would occur in usual care over that timeframe for a multidisciplinary evaluation. However, the follow-up does not appear to be overly burdensome.
Score: [3]

Primary outcome:
Quotes: "The primary outcome was the impact of the strategy on quality of life (QoL) measured using the MSIS-29 scale at inclusion and after six months."
Reasoning: The primary outcome is quality of life measured by the MSIS-29, a patient-reported outcome that is relevant to participants. Using a patient-reported QoL measure is a pragmatic choice. The timepoint of 6 months is somewhat arbitrary but reasonably pragmatic.
Score: [4]

Primary analysis:
Quotes: "Fifty MS patients were included." "For the sample size, calculations were based on a preliminary study,12 including 40 MS patients. In this pilot study a mean improvement of 10 points over six months on the MSIS-29 scale in the IMD group and a mean worsening of six points in the control group was observed. The standard deviation for the change in the MSIS-29 was 14 points. With the same hypotheses, 22 patients per group were necessary to provide the study a power of 90% with a type 1 error rate of 0.05. To take into account a possible dropout rate, we randomized 25 patients per group."
Reasoning: The analysis appears to have included all 50 randomized patients (25 per group). There is no mention of excluding any participants from the analysis. This suggests an intention-to-treat approach was likely used, which is pragmatic. However, the lack of clarity on whether the analysis was truly intention-to-treat or per-protocol limits a fully pragmatic score.
Score: [4]

llm_message:
Eligibility:
Quotes: "Thirty community dwelling adults moderately affected by MS (Expanded Disability Status Scale 5-6.5)."
"Ethical approval was received from the West of Scotland Research Ethics Service (ref: 12/WS/0147) and participants were recruited from the Multiple Sclerosis Service, at the Douglas Grant Rehabilitation Centre, Irvine, Scotland."
Reasoning: The trial recruited participants from a Multiple Sclerosis Service at a rehabilitation center. While this represents the type of patients that would receive the intervention in usual care, there were some restrictions on eligibility like EDSS score 5-6.5. This makes the eligibility criteria somewhat more restrictive than what would be used in usual care.
Score: [4]

Recruitment:
Quotes: "Ethical approval was received from the West of Scotland Research Ethics Service (ref: 12/WS/0147) and participants were recruited from the Multiple Sclerosis Service, at the Douglas Grant Rehabilitation Centre, Irvine, Scotland."
Reasoning: Participants were recruited from a Multiple Sclerosis service at a rehabilitation center they were already attending. This seems to align with how recruitment would occur in usual care, without extra efforts to recruit participants.
Score: [5]

Setting:
Quotes: "A randomized controlled pilot study. Setting: Rehabilitation centre and participants' homes."
Reasoning: The intervention was delivered via a website that participants accessed from their homes. This matches the setting of usual care for a web-based physiotherapy intervention. The rehabilitation center was only used for recruitment and some assessments.
Score: [5]  

Organization:
Quotes: "The website, which was used to deliver the intervention, was developed in collaboration with a patient steering group and incorporating recommendations from the MS Society accessibility policy and advice from the British Accessibility Information Forum."
"Individualised therapeutic exercise programmes were developed for participants in Group 1, with exercises selected based on their baseline assessment and personal goals."
Reasoning: The web-based physiotherapy intervention required some additional organization compared to usual care, including developing individualized exercise programs for each participant and creating a website in collaboration with patient groups. However, once implemented, the delivery of the intervention did not require extra staff or resources beyond what would be available in usual care.
Score: [3]

Flexibility (delivery):
Quotes: "Participants were given unique log-in details to view their own, online personalised exercise programme. This was a pragmatic study with the content of the web-based programme being similar to the content if it had been delivered face-to-face."
"Participants were advised to undertake the exercise programme a minimum of twice a week and to complete their online exercise diary which was seen remotely by the physiotherapist."
Reasoning: The intervention allowed some flexibility in how it was delivered, with participants accessing their personalized exercise program online on their own schedule at least twice a week. This is similar to the flexibility that would be allowed in usual care. However, participants were remotely monitored by the physiotherapist to discuss progress and update programs as appropriate.
Score: [4]

Flexibility (adherence):
Quotes: "Participants were advised to undertake the exercise programme a minimum of twice a week and to complete their online exercise diary which was seen remotely by the physiotherapist."
Reasoning: Participants were advised to complete their exercise program at least twice a week, but no strict measures were taken to improve or enforce adherence. Adherence was monitored remotely by the physiotherapist viewing exercise diaries. This represents flexibility in adherence similar to what would be expected in usual care.
Score: [4]

Follow-up:
Quotes: "Outcome measures were recorded at baseline and at the end of the intervention period (week 13). The primary outcome measure, the timed 25 foot walk, has good reliability and validity in the MS population."
Reasoning: Follow-up assessments were done only at baseline and at the end of the 12-week intervention period. This matches the intensity of follow-up that would be expected in usual care for a physiotherapy intervention. No extra unscheduled visits or overly burdensome data collection were required.
Score: [5]

Primary outcome:
Quotes: "The primary outcome measure, the timed 25 foot walk, has good reliability and validity in the MS population."
Reasoning: The primary outcome of timed 25 foot walk is a clinically relevant, functional outcome that matters to patients with MS. It does not rely on surrogates, central adjudication, or specialized assessment not available in usual care.
Score: [5]

Primary analysis:
Quotes: "All analysis was performed on SPSS v20 with power calculations for a future fully powered trial being estimated using nQuery v7."
Reasoning: The statistical analysis section does not specify the use of intention-to-treat analysis or provide details on how missing data was handled. There is not enough information provided to fully assess how pragmatic the primary analysis was.
Score: [NA]

Eligibility:
Quotes: "Eighty-five treatment-naïve people with Multiple Sclerosis with persistent (>three months) foot drop." "Participants were screened for eligibility, and written informed consent was gained prior to randomization."

Setting:
Quotes: "Seven Multiple Sclerosis outpatient centres across Scotland – Ayrshire & Arran, Greater Glasgow & Clyde, Dumfries and Galloway, Lanarkshire, Lothian, Fife and Tayside – were informed of the study and issued with a participant information sheet."
The trial took place across seven MS outpatient centers in Scotland. While not explicitly stated, this seems to match a usual care setting for this population. Conducting the trial across multiple standard clinical sites suggests a pragmatic approach.

Organization:
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified.
The full text lacks details on how the organization of care delivery in the trial compares to usual care. There is insufficient information to evaluate this domain.

Flexibility (delivery):
Quotes: "Participants in both groups were instructed to gradually increase the wear of their devices over the first six weeks." "The current amplitude ranged from 7 to 72 mA (mean = 40 mA). Participants in both groups were instructed to gradually increase the wear of their devices over the first six weeks."
Participants were instructed to gradually increase device usage over the first six weeks, but few other details are provided on flexibility of intervention delivery. The amplitude range allowed some tailoring. Overall, the delivery appears to be somewhat protocol-driven but not highly rigid.

Flexibility (adherence):
Quotes: "Eighty-five participants were recruited allowing for an approximate 15% attrition rate."
Recruiting additional participants to allow for 15% attrition suggests that the trial had a somewhat pragmatic approach to adherence, not employing strict adherence measures or excluding non-adherent participants. However, the text provides limited details to fully assess flexibility of adherence expected.
Score: [4]

Follow-up:
Quotes: "Participants walked twice, once with their device and once without, at weeks 0, 3, 6 and 12 months; 5-minute self-selected walk test (primary)." "The order of testing was randomized between participants but was kept consistent for each participant throughout the trial."
Participants underwent assessments with a 5-minute walk test at baseline and 3, 6, and 12 months. This schedule is more frequent than typical follow-up in usual care. However, the 5-minute test itself is not particularly burdensome. The follow-up is therefore somewhat more intensive than usual care but not excessively so.

Quotes: "The primary outcome was walking speed as measured by the 5-minute self-selected walk test." "A minimum of 37 participants were required to detect a change of at least 75% of 1 standard deviation value (0.16 m/s) to achieve a power of 90% at a 5% level of significance."
Walking speed measured by a 5-minute self-selected walk test appears to be a clinically meaningful and patient-centered outcome. The outcome itself is relevant to participants. However, the test may be administered in a more structured manner than done in routine practice.
Score: [4]

Primary analysis:
Quotes: "Eighty-five participants were recruited allowing for an approximate 15% attrition rate." "All analysis was performed on IBM SPSS v24, using a 5% level of significance (IBM, New York, USA)."
The trial recruited 85 participants to allow for 15% attrition, suggesting that the primary analysis likely included most participants. However, it is not explicitly stated that an intention-to-treat approach analyzing all randomized participants was used. More details would be needed to determine how pragmatic the analysis was.

llm_message:
Eligibility:
Quotes:
"Adults with severe MS-carer dyads were assigned (2:1 ratio) to either HPA or usual care (UC)."
"At each center, a multi-professional team delivered the 6-month intervention. A blind examiner assessed dyads at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months."
Reasoning: The trial included adults with severe MS and their carers, which is likely similar to the population that would receive this intervention as part of usual care. However, the trial also involved a multi-professional team delivering the intervention and blind examiners assessing participants, which may differ from usual care.
Score: [3]

Recruitment:
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified.
Reasoning: The full text does not provide details on how participants were recruited for the trial, such as whether recruitment was done through usual appointments/clinics or if extra effort like invitation letters or advertising was used. There is insufficient information to assess how pragmatic or explanatory the recruitment was compared to usual care.
Score: [NA]

Setting:
Quotes: "We performed a multicenter RCT involving adults with severe MS and their carers to assess the effectiveness of a home-based palliative approach (HPA) added to usual care (UC)."
Reasoning: The trial was conducted in multiple centers and involved a home-based intervention, which suggests the setting may be similar to usual care. However, without more details on the specific centers involved, it is difficult to determine if they are identical to the usual care setting or if some may be more specialized trial centers.
Score: [4]

Organization:
Quotes:
"At each center, a multi-professional team delivered the 6-month intervention."
"HPs. On average, dyads received 4.9 home visits in the first 3 months and 2.8 in the second 3 months. The nurse (team leader) performed 152 visits (33%), followed by the psychologist (25%), the physician (25%), and the social worker (17%)."
Reasoning: The intervention involved a multi-professional team delivering home visits, which likely requires greater staff expertise and resources than what is typically available in usual care. The number and frequency of visits from various health professionals also suggests the organization of care delivery in the intervention arm differs from usual care.
Score: [2]

Flexibility (delivery):
Quotes: "Based on the principles of PC,17 each center had a HPA team consisting of a physician (neurologist or physiatrist), a nurse (case manager and team leader), a psychologist, and a social worker. Nurses of the Milan and Rome centers had degrees and worked full time in PC; the Catania nurse attended a week-long individual training course."
Reasoning: The intervention followed defined principles of palliative care and involved a specified team composition and some training, suggesting a less flexible delivery than usual care. However, the extent of flexibility in the delivery is not fully clear from the information provided.
Score: [3]

Flexibility (adherence):
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified.
Reasoning: The full text does not discuss flexibility in how participants could adhere to the intervention or if any measures were taken to improve adherence. Surgical or ICU trials where adherence is not an issue after consent are also not mentioned. There is insufficient information provided to assess flexibility of adherence.
Score: [NA] 

Follow-up:
Quotes: 
"A blind examiner assessed dyads at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months."
"0 dyads were lost to follow-up; 4 dyads discontinued intervention; - 3 patients died (one after 12-week visit); - 1 withdrew consent (before 12-week visit); 1 dyad did not perform visit 3"
Reasoning: Dyads were assessed at baseline, 3 months and 6 months, with few participants lost to follow-up and some discontinuing the intervention. This represents a moderately intensive follow-up schedule. However, without knowing the typical follow-up in usual care, it is difficult to determine if this is more or less intensive than usual.
Score: [3]

Primary outcome:
Quotes:
"Primary outcome measures were Palliative care Outcome Scale-Symptoms-MS (POS-S-MS) and Schedule for the Evaluation of Individual Quality of Life-Direct Weighting (SEIQoL-DW, not assessed in severely cognitively compromised patients)."
"Mean change in POS-S-MS score from baseline to 3 months was 1.1 (95% confidence interval (CI), −0.5 to 2.7) in the HPA group and −0.2 (95% CI, −2.9 to 2.6) in the UC group, with a mean between-group difference of 1.3 (95% CI, −1.7 to 4.2), and a Cohen's d effect size (ES) of 0.20."
Reasoning: The primary outcomes of POS-S-MS and SEIQoL-DW appear to be relevant to participants, as they measure palliative care symptoms and quality of life. The outcomes are patient-reported and do not seem to require assessment expertise unavailable in usual care. The timing of outcome assessment is not clearly compared to usual care.
Score: [4]

Primary analysis:
Quotes:
"50 dyads were analyzed; 2 dyads were excluded from analysis; - 2 did not receive allocated intervention"
Reasoning: 50 out of the 52 randomized dyads were included in the primary analysis. The 2 excluded dyads did not receive the allocated intervention, so this is not a strict intention-to-treat approach. However, the analysis still included a high proportion of the randomized participants.
Score: [4]

llm_message:
Eligibility:
Quotes:
1) "Participants randomised to the CLP arm of the trial received current local practice advice and information provision about MS-fatigue to more detailed individualised management advice from a variety of health professionals."
2) "Individuals who had attended a fatigue management programme in the past 3 months (see protocol col)."
Reasoning: The trial included participants who would likely receive the intervention if it was part of usual care, with only those who recently attended a fatigue management program being excluded. However, some additional eligibility criteria were applied that may differ from usual care.
Score: [4]

Recruitment:
Quotes:
1) "Recruitment was 39 from the South West, 75 from the Poole centre and 50 from the Poole centre."
Reasoning: Recruitment was done through the participating centers, which appears to be a pragmatic approach similar to usual care. No additional efforts for recruitment beyond what would occur in usual care are mentioned.
Score: [5]

Setting:
Quotes:
1) "Three-centre parallel arm randomised controlled trial with economic evaluation. Patients with MS and significant fatigue were randomised to FACETS or current local practice."
Reasoning: The trial was conducted in three centers, which is relatively pragmatic and likely similar to the usual care setting for delivering this type of intervention. However, with only three centers involved, there may be some differences compared to the full spectrum of usual care settings.
Score: [4]

Organization:
Quotes:
1) "The main inclusion criteria were: (1) clinically definite MS diagnosis, (2) fatigue impacting on daily life (Fatigue Severity Scale score >4) and (3) ambulatory. The main exclusion criteria were: (1) having taken part in a fatigue programme in the last year, (2) cognitive impairments, (3) a relapse in the previous 3 months or (4) having started treatment with disease modifying or antidepressant drugs within the previous 3 months."
2) "Participants were recruited in three UK centres (Poole, Bristol, Southampton/Portsmouth) from primary or secondary care, or via MS Society newsletters/websites."
Reasoning: The trial utilized staff with expertise in delivering the FACETS intervention and had some additional organization compared to usual care, such as the inclusion/exclusion criteria and recruitment from MS Society newsletters/websites. However, the intervention was still integrated within existing healthcare services.
Score: [3]

Flexibility (delivery):
Quotes:
1) "The aim of the intervention is to help people normalise their fatigue experiences, learn helpful ways of thinking about fatigue and use their available energy more effectively. The intervention consists of six sessions (∼90 min duration) held weekly and facilitated in groups of 6–12 by two health professionals with experience of working with people with MS and group-work (such as occupational therapists, nurses or physiotherapists)."
Reasoning: The intervention followed a structured format of six weekly 90-minute sessions delivered by trained health professionals. While this is likely more structured than usual care, the group format and facilitation by existing staff types allows for some pragmatic flexibility.
Score: [3]

Flexibility (adherence):
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified. The trial did not appear to discuss flexibility of participant adherence.
Score: [NA]

Follow-up:
Quotes:
1) "A total of 164 people were randomised (time from primary care) (figure 1). First follow-up data are available for 146 (89%) and second follow-up for 144 (88%). Recruitment was 39 from the South West, 75 from the Southampton/Portsmouth Centre and 50 from the Poole centre. In all, 84 participants were randomised to FACETS and 80 to CLP. Overall, 10 FACETS programmes were run with group sizes ranging from 4 to 11 (mean=7.4; SD=2.1)."
Reasoning: Follow-up data collection occurred at two timepoints after the intervention, which is likely somewhat more intensive than usual care follow-up. However, the follow-up was largely questionnaire-based which is a relatively pragmatic approach.
Score: [4]

Primary outcome:
Quotes:
1) "The primary 'intention-to-treat' analyses and results for the primary outcome measures are shown in table 2 and online supplementary figure S1. There were statistically significantly greater improvements in fatigue self-efficacy in the FACETS arm at follow-up 1 compared with the CLP arm."
2) "Statistically significant differences favour the CLP arm, but these are small, and not statistically significant."
Reasoning: The primary outcome measures of fatigue self-efficacy and fatigue severity were highly relevant to participants. The measures were self-reported using validated scales. This represents a pragmatic approach, although some of the measures like the SF-36 may be less commonly used in usual care.

Primary analysis:
Quotes:
1) "The main analysis was intention-to-treat but we also conducted a 'per protocol' analysis (excluding participants who attended fewer than four FACETS sessions)."

original_llm_message:

Setting:

1) "Three-centre parallel arm randomised controlled trial with economic evaluation. Patients with MS and significant fatigue were randomised to FACETS or current local practice."

Score: [4]

Organization:
Quotes:
1) "The main inclusion criteria were: (1) clinically definite MS diagnosis, (2) fatigue impacting on daily life (Fatigue Severity Scale score >4) and (3) ambulatory. The main exclusion criteria were: (1) having taken part in a fatigue programme in the last year, (2) cognitive impairments, (3) a relapse in the previous 3 months or (4) having started treatment with disease modifying or antidepressant drugs within the previous 3 months."
2) "Participants were recruited in three UK centres (Poole, Bristol, Southampton/Portsmouth) from primary or secondary care, or via MS Society newsletters/websites."
Reasoning: The trial utilized staff with expertise in delivering the FACETS intervention and had some additional organization compared to usual care, such as the inclusion/exclusion criteria and recruitment from MS Society newsletters/websites. However, the intervention was still integrated within existing healthcare services.

Flexibility (delivery):
Quotes:
1) "The aim of the intervention is to help people normalise their fatigue experiences, learn helpful ways of thinking about fatigue and use their available energy more effectively. The intervention consists of six sessions (∼90 min duration) held weekly and facilitated in groups of 6–12 by two health professionals with experience of working with people with MS and group-work (such as occupational therapists, nurses or physiotherapists)."
Reasoning: The intervention followed a structured format of six weekly 90-minute sessions delivered by trained health professionals. While this is likely more structured than usual care, the group format and facilitation by existing staff types allows for some pragmatic flexibility.

Reasoning: Follow-up data collection occurred at two timepoints after the intervention, which is likely somewhat more intensive than usual care follow-up. However, the follow-up was largely questionnaire-based which is a relatively pragmatic approach.
