llm_message:
Eligibility
Quotes:
1. "Practices were recruited with assistance from Primary Care Research Networks for London, Derby, and Nottingham. Patients aged ≥65 years were identified by searches of computerised medical records and invited to participate if they were: • community dwelling aged ≥65 years; • independently mobile (with or without a walking aid); and • physically able to take part in group exercise."
2. "Patients were excluded if they: • had experienced ≥3 falls in the previous year; • had unstable clinical conditions; • would be unable to follow instructions about exercise safely; or • were receiving palliative care."

The trial recruited participants from primary care practices with some exclusion criteria, such as those with ≥3 falls in the previous year, unstable clinical conditions, inability to follow exercise instructions safely, or receiving palliative care. However, the inclusion criteria were relatively broad, including those aged ≥65 years who were community-dwelling, independently mobile, and physically able to do group exercise. This represents a moderately pragmatic approach, as the participants are generally representative of older primary care patients, with some reasonable exclusions.
Score: [3]

Recruitment
Quotes: 
1. "Practices were recruited with assistance from Primary Care Research Networks for London, Derby, and Nottingham."
2. "Patients aged ≥65 years were identified by searches of computerised medical records and invited to participate if they were: • community dwelling aged ≥65 years; • independently mobile (with or without a walking aid); and • physically able to take part in group exercise."

Recruitment was done through primary care practices with the assistance of research networks, which is similar to how patients would be identified for such an intervention in usual care. Eligible patients were identified through electronic medical record searches and invited to participate, which is a pragmatic approach not requiring much additional effort beyond usual methods.
Score: [4]

Setting
Quotes:
1. "Participants were followed up at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months at their general practice or usual care venue."
2. "The trial took place in a group once a week and included exercises to be carried out at home, unsupervised, twice weekly. The OEP was undertaken at home, unsupervised, and comprised exercises to be done three times per week."

The interventions and follow-up assessments were carried out in the participants' usual general practices or community venues, which matches the setting of usual care.
Score: [5]

Organization
Quotes:
1. "The FaME intervention took place in a group once a week and included exercises to be carried out at home, unsupervised, twice weekly. The OEP was undertaken at home, unsupervised, and comprised exercises to be done three times per week."
2. "Volunteer peer mentors supported participants in the OEP arm, and weekly FaME classes were run in local venues by postural stability instructors trained to work with older people. Both interventions were delivered for 24 weeks. Participants in the usual-care arm were not offered either programme."

The interventions required some additional organization compared to usual care, including group classes run by trained postural stability instructors for the FaME arm, and the involvement of volunteer peer mentors to support the OEP arm. However, the exercises were carried out unsupervised at home. This represents a moderate increase in organization compared to usual care.
Score: [3]

Flexibility (delivery)
Quotes:
1. "The FaME intervention took place in a group once a week and included exercises to be carried out at home, unsupervised, twice weekly. The OEP was undertaken at home, unsupervised, and comprised exercises to be done three times per week."
2. "Volunteer peer mentors supported participants in the OEP arm, and weekly FaME classes were run in local venues by postural stability instructors trained to work with older people."

The interventions had a protocol in terms of the frequency and general content of the group classes and home exercises. However, the exercises were undertaken unsupervised at home, allowing some flexibility in how they were carried out. The use of peer mentors and postural stability instructors trained to work with older people also suggests the delivery could be adapted to individual participants to some extent.
Score: [3]

Flexibility (adherence)
Quotes: 
1. "Participants in the FaME arm, compared with usual care, reported more MVPA at 12 months, adding around 15 minutes of MVPA per day."
2. "The odds ratios for reaching the target of 150 minutes of MVPA per week in the FaME arm was 1.78 (95% confidence interval [CI] =1.11 to 2.87, P = 0.02). There was no statistically significant difference in reaching the target between the OEP and usual-care arms (OR 1.17 [95% CI = 0.72 to 1.92], P = 0.52)."

The study reported on adherence measures, suggesting that adherence was encouraged but not required. Participants in the FaME arm had higher odds of reaching the target MVPA levels compared to usual care, but there was no significant difference between OEP and usual care. This indicates that participants had flexibility in their level of adherence to the interventions.
Score: [4]

Follow-up
Quotes:
1. "Participants were followed up at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months at their general practice or usual care venue."
2. "Participants were analysed in the groups to which they were randomised, regardless of whether they received the intervention or not, and multiple imputation was used to include all participants in the analyses."

Follow-up assessments were carried out at baseline, 6 months and 12 months, which exceeds the intensity of follow-up that would occur in usual care. However, the assessments took place at the participants' general practices or usual care venues, consistent with a pragmatic approach. The use of intention-to-treat analysis and multiple imputation to include all participants is also pragmatic.
Score: [3]

Primary outcome
Quotes:
1. "The proportions reporting at least 150 minutes of MVPA per week rose from 40% (136/342) to 49% (95/193) in the FaME arm, 41% (150/362) to 43% (99/185) in the OEP arm, and 37.5% (150/400) to 38% (84/222) in the usual-care arm; 12 months after the end of the intervention."
2. "The primary outcome was the proportion of participants who reported reaching ≥150 minutes of MVPA per week. Physical activity was assessed using validated questionnaires: Phone-FITT, the Physical Activity Scale for the Elderly (PASE), and the Community Healthy Activities Model Program for Seniors (CHAMPS). The primary outcome measure was the CHAMPS questionnaire."

The primary outcome of proportion of participants achieving at least 150 minutes of moderate to vigorous physical activity (MVPA) per week is highly relevant to the participants and consistent with guidelines for older adults. It was assessed using self-reported validated questionnaires, which are feasible measures for use in regular clinical practice, although some bias in self-reporting is possible.
Score: [4]

Primary analysis
Quotes:
1. "Participants were analysed in the groups to which they were randomised, regardless of whether they received the intervention or not, and multiple imputation was used to include all participants in the analyses."
2. "Baseline characteristics were compared informally between treatment arms. Comparisons between treatment arms were made using random-effects regression models to allow for clustering between practices."

The primary analysis was conducted using intention-to-treat principles, analyzing participants in their assigned groups regardless of actual treatment received. Multiple imputation was used to include all randomized participants. This is a pragmatic approach, aiming to estimate the real-world effectiveness of the intervention.
Score: [5]
original_llm_message:
Eligibility
Quotes:
1. "Practices were recruited with assistance from Primary Care Research Networks for London, Derby, and Nottingham. Patients aged ≥65 years were identified by searches of computerised medical records and invited to participate if they were: • community dwelling aged ≥65 years; • independently mobile (with or without a walking aid); and • physically able to take part in group exercise."
2. "Patients were excluded if they: • had experienced ≥3 falls in the previous year; • had unstable clinical conditions; • would be unable to follow instructions about exercise safely; or • were receiving palliative care."

The trial recruited participants from primary care practices with some exclusion criteria, such as those with ≥3 falls in the previous year, unstable clinical conditions, inability to follow exercise instructions safely, or receiving palliative care. However, the inclusion criteria were relatively broad, including those aged ≥65 years who were community-dwelling, independently mobile, and physically able to do group exercise. This represents a moderately pragmatic approach, as the participants are generally representative of older primary care patients, with some reasonable exclusions.

Eligible patients were identified through electronic medical record searches and invited to participate, which is a pragmatic approach not requiring much additional effort beyond usual methods.
